title: Building Emotional Awareness
summary: Help your child recognize, label, and express their emotions in healthy ways.

details.content: Children with emotional or behavioral disorders often struggle to identify and communicate their feelings, which can lead to frustration and outbursts.
When your child is upset, encourage them to name their feeling (e.g., 'I feel angry') and talk about what caused it.

content: Model emotional labeling by sharing your own feelings out loud.
Use emotion charts or faces to help your child identify emotions.
Validate your child's feelings, even if you don't agree with their behavior.
Encourage regular check-ins about emotions during calm moments.

title: Effective Communication Techniques
summary: Use clear, calm, and consistent communication to foster understanding and cooperation.

details.content: Effective communication reduces misunderstandings and helps children feel heard and respected.
Instead of saying 'Stop yelling!', try 'I hear you're upset. Let's use a quieter voice so I can understand you.'

content: Use 'I' statements to express your feelings and needs.
Maintain eye contact and use a calm tone.
Give clear, simple instructions and check for understanding.
Listen actively and reflect back what your child says.

title: Consistent Routines and Boundaries
summary: Establish predictable routines and clear boundaries to provide structure and security.

details.content: Consistency helps children feel safe and know what to expect, reducing anxiety and behavioral issues.
Having a set bedtime routine helps your child transition calmly to sleep each night.

content: Create visual schedules for daily routines.
Clearly explain rules and consequences ahead of time.
Follow through consistently with established boundaries.
Review routines regularly and adjust as needed.

title: Positive Reinforcement
summary: Encourage desired behaviors by acknowledging and rewarding them.

details.content: Positive reinforcement increases the likelihood of good behavior and builds your child's self-esteem.
Praise your child for using words to express frustration instead of acting out.

content: Offer specific praise (e.g., 'I like how you cleaned up your toys.').
Use reward systems like sticker charts for younger children.
Celebrate small successes to build momentum.
Be consistent and immediate with positive feedback.

title: Collaborative Problem Solving
summary: Work together with your child to find solutions to challenges and conflicts.

details.content: Involving your child in problem-solving teaches responsibility and improves cooperation.
If your child struggles with homework time, brainstorm together ways to make it easier.

content: Ask open-ended questions to understand your child's perspective.
Encourage your child to suggest solutions.
Evaluate options together and agree on a plan.
Follow up and adjust the plan as needed.

title: Self-Care for Parents
summary: Prioritize your own well-being to better support your child.

details.content: Caring for a child with emotional or behavioral challenges can be stressful; self-care helps you stay resilient and patient.
Take time for activities you enjoy, like reading or walking, to recharge your energy.

content: Schedule regular breaks and downtime.
Seek support from friends, family, or parent groups.
Practice stress-reduction techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness.
Recognize and honor your own limits.

title: Seeking Professional Support
summary: Reach out to mental health professionals or support services when needed.

details.content: Professional guidance can provide new strategies, resources, and emotional support for both you and your child.
Consult a therapist or counselor if your child's behaviors are overwhelming or not improving.

content: Research local mental health resources and support groups.
Don't hesitate to ask for help when you need it.
Collaborate with teachers, counselors, and healthcare providers.
Stay informed about your child's diagnosis and treatment options.
